 In hopes of having a discussion, here are some of my opinions on truth and reality. Metaphysics itself can never lead us to an incontestable understanding of absolute truth wrt reality, and certainly science never can, but it is fun thinking out loud about such things. So here's where I stand. At least, here's where I stand, for now.
 
 
 Truth is an epistemological abstraction. It does not include ontological reality, per se. That is, truth refers to relation between what "is", 'ontological reality', and what is "known", thought, believed, imagined or proposed wrt to it. The volitional exercise made to establish the quality of this realation, i.e., 'true', or 'false' is called epistemology. Science is one form of epistemology.
 
 The degree of correspondence in the scientific study of this relation is known as its "truth value", and that value based on the degree of predictability conferred by the epistemological construct of cause/effect regularity. That predictability, in turn, is based upon the consistency of the relation between observation and expectation, as determined, 'a posteriori'. An apple, left to its own devices, is always seen to fall to the ground, sooner or later. Hence the 'truth' of the generalization--"All apples fall to the ground. Sooner or later, these apples, including this apple, will fall to the ground." The truth of that statement lies not in the apple nor in the ground, but in the behaviour of the apple vis a vis the ground. Hence, inductive logic, or inductively conceived 'truth', based upon past observation and present testing against a proposed future event.
 
 Such a truth is dependent upon generally shared experience. If anyone can demonstrate that in certain situations involving apples and 'ground', apples fail to fall to it no matter how long one waits, then the above epistemologically derived truth statment loses value. It goes from being absolutely true, to being relatively true.
 
 But, as everyone knows, certain issues are simply not amenable to inductive logic. That is, certain postulates about ontological reality cannot be arrived at via repeated sensory experience of certain specified behaviours. These postulates can only be arrived at as axioms of ontology, itself.
 
 Some of the most important axioms of ontologically, i.e., a priori, 'reality',are that A/The "world" which I observe exists independently of my observation of it, and is not generated by me. Solipsists deny this postulate. 
 B/ That which we observe has definite properties, and by means of examining the variation in properties between what is observed in one instance, compared with another, we can discriminate between what something is and what something is not. That is, we can legitimately divide reality into different things, at least as different parts of larger things, based upon different observed properties at a given level of reduction. 
 C/ This differentiation in identity creates the reality of time and space, because if "A" is not "B" in terms of properties, then "A" and "B" cannot co-exist at the same point in time and space. In the same fashion, time and space cannot exist in a reality in which a differences in properties have been eliminated and what remains is a single homogeneous entity, "A", and nothing else. 
 D/Nothing can arise from nothing. There is no such thing as "Creatio ex nihilo". All that exists presently is dependent upon something that pre-existed it. Nothing can generate, "de novo", "sui generis", any quality that it as a whole, or in its parts considered individually, did not have previously. Something external to what was must be involved in order to account for what it has become. Nothing is able to spontaneously generate its own existence, in whole or in part.
 
 Working deductively from these 'a priori' logical axioms, i.e., 'truth statements', a certain metaphysical 'truth value' can be determined wrt to inferences abstracted from empirical observations.
 
 Putting the axiomatic together with the observed is as close as we can get to a 'true' understanding of reality.
